title: FirstFT: G7 explores energy price caps
text:
G7 leaders yesterday condemned Russia's “abominable attack” on a shopping mall in a central Ukrainian city as they explored new to ways curb soaring energy costs.

Meeting in the Bavarian Alps, the leaders of the richest democracies said the attack on the Amstor mall, close to the centre of Kremenchuk, could constitute “a war crime”.

At least 18 people were killed in the attack, according to rescue workers, while scores of civilians were wounded in the strike. Ukrainian officials said about 1,000 people were in the building at the time of the attack.

Russia's defence ministry said today that its forces fired missiles at a weapons depot in the city and the subsequent explosion of ammunition triggered a fire at the nearby shopping mall.

Hours before the attack Ukraine's president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, via a video link, called on G7 leaders to continue to provide financial, humanitarian and military support for Ukraine “for as long as it takes”.

According to a draft text seen by the Financial Times, G7 leaders will today explore the “feasibility” of introducing temporary price caps on imports of energy — a reference to a US-led push for a ceiling on the Russian oil price on the final day of their summit.

The move on price caps comes alongside a French proposal for higher global oil production, an idea that arose as G7 leaders sought ways to ease the looming energy crunch and alleviate the pressure on energy-importing economies.

French officials focused yesterday's discussions on ways of moderating prices via higher oil output. In particular, France wants to explore ways of bringing production from Venezuela and Iran, both subject to US sanctions, back on the market.

  • Read more: Gideon Rachman argues why he thinks the US could be the real winner in the energy wars.

Thanks to all the readers who voted in yesterday's poll. Four-fifths of you disagreed with the Supreme Court's decision to strike down Roe vs Wade. If you have any thoughts about this newsletter you can now hit reply and send a message directly. Here's the rest of today's news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. Exclusive: ExxonMobil chief predicts continuing surge in oil markets Darren Woods has predicted a resurgence of investment in fossil fuels on the back of soaring oil and gas prices. The chief executive of ExxonMobil, the west's biggest oil and gas supermajor, told the Financial Times efforts to reduce emissions by cutting production before addressing consumption had left the world struggling to meet its energy needs.

2. Officials say 46 migrants found dead in tractor trailer in Texas Forty-six people believed to be migrants to the US were found dead in and around an abandoned tractor trailer in San Antonio, Texas, yesterday evening. Local officials said another 16 people, including four children, were taken to hospital with signs of heat stroke and exhaustion.

3. Stress tests drive higher capital requirements at three biggest US banks JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup have been hit with higher capital requirements by the Federal Reserve following stress tests from the central bank that probed the lenders' ability to weather a severe recession.

4. White House weighs helping women cross state lines to access abortions The Biden administration is exploring ways to help women who need to travel across state lines to end a pregnancy, including travel vouchers and aid for child care, in response to draconian abortion bans being rolled out in conservative states across the US.

5. Trump's Spac deal plans suffer blow after subpoenas Donald Trump's plans to take his media business public have suffered a blow after a federal grand jury issued subpoenas to a blank-cheque company that is set to merge with Trump Media and Technology Group.

The day ahead

Nato meeting Officials from 30 member countries gather for three days in Madrid as Spain marks 40 years since joining the transatlantic alliance. Speaking ahead of the summit, Turkey's president Recep Tayyip Erdoğan said Ankara would block the accession of Finland and Sweden to Nato unless they offered tangible commitments on combating the activities of Kurdish militias. Follow the latest news from the summit on our live blog.

Ghislaine Maxwell sentencing The British socialite and former girlfriend of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein will be sentenced today in a Manhattan federal court. Maxwell was found guilty in December by a New York jury of five of the six counts filed against her. One of the five charges, criminal sex trafficking, carries a maximum 40-year sentence.

January 6 Committee hearings: The House committee investigating the January 6, 2021 attack on the US Capitol will hold its sixth public hearing in Washington. Last week, the committee said there would be no further hearings until July, but the committee has added an additional hearing to present recently obtained evidence and receive witness testimony.

Covid-19 vaccine ruling The US Food and Drug Administration will convene today to discuss whether Covid-19 vaccines should be modified to include an Omicron variant strain before rollout in the autumn.

Economic data The US Census Bureau will report the latest US trade deficit. The Case-Shiller 20-city composite index is released and expected to have climbed 21 per cent year over year in April, according to a Refinitiv poll of economists, and data from the Conference Board is expected to show consumer confidence weakened in June.

US state primaries Colorado, Illinois, New York, Utah, Mississippi, South Carolina, Oklahoma and Nebraska will hold primary elections today.

What else we're reading

US company spending on private jets soars Spending by US companies on private jets for personal use by chief executives and chairs hit the highest level for a decade last year as many businesses relaxed restrictions on using them because of the pandemic. Facebook parent Meta was among the biggest spenders.

Xi's fraying relationship with the Chinese middle class After a return to gruelling lockdowns under President Xi Jinping's zero-Covid policy, a new trend has emerged in China: runxue. Trapped in a web of unpredictable and chaotic lockdown rules, many Chinese are now dreaming of a permanent escape.

The revival of eastern Germany Once a byword for economic decline, Germany's formerly communist east has become home to Europe's rapidly expanding electric car sector, turning the region into one of the continent's hottest pieces of industrial real estate. Here's how it happened.

Young men are slipping through the economy's cracks The biggest driver of the decline in youth worklessness in recent decades is the collapse in the number of stay-at-home young mothers. But there is another hidden story: the proportion of inactive young men has climbed from 5 per cent in 2000 to 9 per cent last year. Sarah O'Connor goes deeper.

What's a good (and bad) way to leave your job? We too often fail to manage job endings well. The consequences not only affect the person leaving, but can also harm staff remaining — and the company itself. Naomi Shragai, a business psychotherapist and author, shares tips for amicable endings.

Obituary

Leonardo Del Vecchio, the billionaire founder of Italian eyewear group Luxottica, has died at the age of 87. Raised in an orphanage, Del Vecchio went on to build a personal fortune of more than €24bn and become Italy's second-richest man.
